comments.commentBody: I too ran for office and  was asked the same stupid questions,whose going to take care of your children? Double standards abound in American society! Let's pray that modern men and  women will support the best candidate. Other highly developed societies have,so whats up with the south? Ann Richards was one of the best governors of the "Great State of Texas" so let's make her proud.

She became an icon for pro choice feminists, who want her to win based on her strong pro-woman stance. To win the "would you have a beer with her/him" test she needs to frame herself as a regular gal. In many ways she is already because what, really, is "regular?" She's smarter than most people, if we can agree that getting into and succeeding at Harvard Law demands an exceptional intellect. So, to get there she needed a man's money and help with her children? Those who cry foul either don't agree with her policy positions or are sorely disappointed that she had privileges that supposed "regular" single moms don't typically have.

I hate politics. Yet sometimes I wish I could run for office so people would snoop around in my closet. I would be totally transparent about everything (which means I'd probably never actually make it onto a ballot). I would have no trouble telling anyone that in order to have a successful career, I relied heavily on my children's grandmothers. And that my single motherhood is mitigated by the fact that I get child support on the first of every month without question.

It is too bad anyone - Ms. Davis or anyone else - feels such pressure to embellish or sugarcoat or downplay or lie by omission about anything personal such as how they raise their children; their sexuality; their youthful indiscretions. It will be nice when most Americans can focus on policy not personal choices.

P.S. Hillary Clinton spells her name with two "L"s.
The fourth Republican response, the one spent swearing at the TV whenever the president says anything, no matter how innocuous, is the most honest one of all.

Yes, and that is exactly the reason investors should reinvest their fossil fuel divestitures into companies focused on expanding the generation and usage of low carbon impact sources and technologies. The goal here is to do the best we can by moving away from fossil fuels and creating economically viable alternatives to them.

I wonder how many of these people use gasoline to drive, heat their houses with gas or oil, and/or get their electricity from gas-fired or coal-fired power plants. Rogue companies? You have to be kidding. Another example of the new faith-based environmental religion - the one the preaches that we can meet our current electric needs, plus the needs of 150,000,000 new electric cars, with windmills, solar and hydro.

Attention:

Children need attention. They need positive attention from role models (teachers) in an orderly environment. They need to form attachments to other students and adults. This is how good social skills, confidence and drive are imbued in children. Too, the sooner the better.

The light you referring to is a train that coming heads on Ukraine. The West is supporting right wing nationalist and Anti Semites. The Ukrainians will not be living together. West and East should and will separate

I do not feel taxpayers should pay for preschool for all children, only for low-income ones. Researchers Garces and Deming and others found the benefit of preschool to be for poor children, with questionable benefits to middle-income ones. My experience is that most preschools are not academic; they teach what many middle income/class parents do at home:  read to them, use language to teach them to speak properly, learn to follow directions (pick up your socks; put them in the hamper; give me the red cup) simple hygiene, etc.

Like most 55-year olds, I have managed to survive in life with no pre-K, and a just a half-day kindergarten where I recall singing, dancing, drawing and napping. The purpose of my half-day K was to acclimate kids to school so they would be ready to learn in the 1st grade.

Now, for some reason, we have to blow taxpayer money to provide every child with full day pre-K, which is nothing more than glorified baby sitting. There is no reason why the I should pay for the babysitting costs of a Wall Street investment banker.

In addition, the 1% tax on incomes over $500,000 is a pittance, and will not come close to funding the huge number of new full-time teachers that will be need (pre-K kids need a low teacher to student ratio), and the new classrooms that will be required, especially in districts that are already at 100% capacity.

Finally, lots of pre-K kids are just not ready to learn anything academic. And pre-K will be academic. So the result will be counterproductive in many instances.

Universal pre-K? No thanks.
Yea right. Wishful thinking. Obamas days are over. Long live Putin

"Real Democracy?" you mean like US with millions on welfare and millions on food stamps and millions on years of unemployment, and millions on some types of disability insurance and millions in jail?
Thanks but NO THANKS. Russian will be choosing its own path of development.

"Mute swans have been severely effecting our ecology in a negative way."
Really? The swans are effecting (sic) the way we study a particular branch of biology? This is the definition of "ecology":
ecology |iˈkäləjē|
noun
1 the branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.

Perhaps you mean they have affected the ecosystem. Am I nitpicking? No. When people don't know the basic terms involved, how can they be expected to understand and properly discuss the complexities of the issue?
http://emcphd.wordpress.com

Destroying native grasses...ruining aquatic vegetation. You might want to do some research on how human sewage is doing that. That is HUMAN SEWAGE.

"The saltwater marsh islands of Jamaica Bay — crucial habitat for dozens of species of fish and birds — are vanishing at a rate far faster than previously thought and could disappear within five years, according to a report scheduled to be released today. .......While experts are not in agreement on what causes the severe losses, scientists suspect that one principal reason is nitrogen pollution from the treated outflow of four city sewage treatment plants on the bay. Large amounts of nitrogen can kill delicate marsh plants, and without the root structures to hold sediment in place, the marsh islands could be quickly washed away. "

http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/02/nyregion/02marsh.html

comments.userDisplayName: Sheila Bolin President CEO The Regal Swan Foundation
comments.commentBody:
IN the DEC's Ecological Status of Mute Swans , they could not definitely state if the Black Tern or other species were actually displaced by the Mutes. Furthermore, the DEC stated that the Mute Swans poop more in water and geese on land, thereby fouling the water and causing more damage to aquatic habitats due to high nitrogen levels. This is a great theory, but even land based poop will eventually get washed into the water. Before blaming one species, there should have been actual DNA sequencing of the poop and nitrogen levels in the watet to determine animal wastes from farms, fertilizers, other waterfowl species or the Mute Swans. This part if the DEC's plan tested only Tundra Swans and then applied their findings to the Mutes as research results. No actual DNA sequencing was conducted.
Again flawed research.

Sheila Bolin The Regal Swan Foundation

Mute swans have been severely effecting our ecology in a negative way. They are exacerbating the decline of such birds such as the egret and so on, by destroying our native grasses. They ruin the the aquatic vegetation needed for lifeforms (invertebrates & vertebrates) to grow into food for our native waterfowl. It is a major environmental issue across the country and hurts the natural life cycle for our habitat and native species that are drastically declining. Some states allow, as an alternative to euthanasia, pinioning and "adoption" for estates and privately owned property, but letting them take over is not good. Also their highly aggressive territorial behavior has caused much trouble for the native tern and black skimmers - ie now a threatened species, because they must abandon their nests.
Right. And humans who have gotten all over the globe by their own devices are barely posing much of a problem. Keep dreaming.

The comparing of humans to other non native species is a weak argument.  Had the mute swan made it here by its own devices such as birds that migrate throughout, this would not pose a problem, just as man used foot bridges at one time in history to get to different continental plates.

Clearly, the writer put her purse in her helmet while shopping at the 99-cent store and then forgot about it when she later put her helmet on.  This is the biker's equivalent to a driver leaving something on the roof or the hood of his or her car and driving off.  Studies show that 99.9% of drivers have done this at least once.  The biker here is no more senile than the 99.9%

As the 2014 elections loom, NY Times has repeatedly printed stories predicting that the Rpublicans will win. However, when on the night of the Presidents State of the Union a Republican Congressman, Mr Grimm makes life threatening gestures and comments to a journalist--- that not on the front page.

It is Republican politicians who are bullies - not just Governor Christie but this Mr Grimm and they are simply inferior candidates in office and we have to get more of them out of the Congress if we want to break gridlock.

Here is Mr Grimm described on the local NY page of of the Times:
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/30/nyregion/rep-michael-grimm-threat-ny1-...

the irony is that that seat is not even gerrymandered containing parts of Brooklyn as well as Staten Island.  Voters are simply asleep-- and it it does not help that this important story was not on the front page-

Gee, you make it sound like reporters are the new battered spouses.   Sorry, but there is more than too much horrible, misleading, down right lying reporting out there to be reigned in before I am going to buy into that pedestal placing gobbledygook.

I've always been cynical about education. My greatest effort was on cramming for finals to pass even though I had a genius IQ and would get lectured even in collage on being lazy. When I did study, I invariably got the highest grades and made enemies. I'm a firm believer that the social order is meant for certain people to become the 1% or leaders and the rest of us are doomed to a Sisyphus life. It's a very good feeling to see a child working to accomplish something and getting a reward but is this the reality we live in? Why is there a subconscious mind? We live in fantasies and refuse to admit this.
Only?

"I may not like the congressman but he is still an elected official; when that deserves no deference, we might as well give up on representative democracy."

So Fredda, you want to live in a society that allows elected officials to threaten physical harm to journalists?

I suggest you move to Iran, Syria, or Russia, to name a few. More your cup of tea.

Let P stand for Princess and p for prince. Moreover Pj will mean Princess is in room j, while pk will mean prince knocks on door of room k. Then by your method we could have the following sequence:
P3p1P2p17P1p2P2p16P1p3P2p15P1... and the prince has missed the princess.
This doesn't work. I posted a counter example early this morning (about 1am) but the blog ate it.
Because the rooms are linearly ordered, clicking 1, then 17, then 2, then 16, then 3, then 15 . . . . will get the princess.
IT'S UNFORTUNATE you didn't mention bernie custis who went from Syracuse to play in the CFL from 1951-56; other black QBs followed in the sixties and seventies.
When Obama was senator, he also voted against raising the debt ceiling. Was he wrong then?

@Concerned Reader: I see this deflection raised all the time.  I assume it can be sourced back to Fox news Agit-prop.  Nobody is saying that all legislators must vote to raise the debt ceiling, that's up to them and their conscience, such as it is.  What they are saying is that there should be an up or down vote to raise the debt ceiling in both houses of Congress.  Instead of that we get the "Hastert Rule" in the House, which prevents the body from even holding a vote unless the Republican majority - including some real mouthbreathers - internally agrees to hold one, and, of course, the odious filibuster in the Senate.  The fact that the President voted whichever way he did has NOTHING to do with these undemocratic shenanigans by which a minority is essentially extorting the rest of us.  Can you understand the difference?  Will you?

I think the most appalling thing the Republicans have recently done was the gridlock which they created over raising the nation’s debt limit, with some of its members loudly proclaiming that it might be a good thing for America to have a government shutdown. I admire Obama for standing strong against that delusional stance, as he knows and understands well the dangers of such reckless talk at home and the perception by other countries of our nation abroad.

These threats, as with similar ones from a year ago by some Republicans, have caused great consternation in the markets world wide, with the Chinese government mocking our nation, questioning our basic policies and advocating a pulling away from the dollar as the pinnacle currency of the world.

Those Republicans who say 'no' to nearly every sensible proposal are the ones who will disavow any connection with what they proposed when their ideas are proven bad ones, political manipulators to the end.

Sherman ain't stupid, take the focus off Wilson. Up against a Manning? Spare me.
Wilson will have his moments. Many more than the Denver faithful will wish.
It will not be about the Denver offense versus the Seattle defense.
More Wilson and that Seattle front line against whatever is coming on that night in of all places, New Jersey.
The article doesn't state it, but presumably he is not an NC State grad. He transferred to Wisconsin after his "demotion". So Wisconsin gets the boasting rights?
He graduated from Wisconsin not NC State. Did you read the article?

Sorry, Chico. He is an NC State Grad. He graduated in 3 years and took Grad courses at Wisconsin, one of the reasons he signed on there for his 4th year of eligibility. They had the courses he wanted.
Full Disclosure: I am a Wisconsin grad and would like to say the the same about Russell Wilson, but I'll settle for his 1 year stint at QB (though I wish he could have pulled off a Rose Bowl win over Oregon.)
Can't say enough about the character of this young man. I am proud to say he is a fellow NC State grad. This world needs many more Russell Wilsons.

Excellent comment. I agree, watch the line play to see who will win the game.
To get the perspective of the other players, check out Nate Jackson's writing for the Times. Search for The Coldest Yard for starters. If you like that piece, read more. And then his fine book Slow Getting Up.
Anyone who played the game would say 'Amen, Brother Jackson!'

Being a teacher at Russell's K-12 school, I can attest to Russell's work ethic, confidence and drive from an early age. None of the issues you raise were part of his make-up. He was never unappreciated, and being under 6 feet only made him work harder. As for what he does in his time off, it has been so well documented how he serves in the community that readers of publications other than the NYT may be tired of hearing about it.

It's cool to write about Wilson, who obviously has had his struggles, what with being African American, undersized, and underappreciated. He's obviously a tremendously hard worker with a sharp intellect and ability to lead. Good for him.

But what about the guys who protect him? The offensive linemen who rarely if ever get any credit for the supremely difficult and laughably uncredited job they perform, week in and week out?

Give the NYT readers some credit and interview some of the offensive line. Or write about how good they are. Peyton has been sacked so infrequently that his jersey has probably been washed like 3 times all season. Why not write about how good they are.

Or write about what these guys do when they aren't practicing or eating or watching game film. How do they spend their time? What are they thinking about?

I get that most sports news sources would eschew the more obscure, less glamorous aspects of the game, especially leading up to the most glamorous moment in the sporting world.

But NYT subscribers want the stuff no other publication will tackle. They think more so they want more. They want to be challenged, to be rewarded with a depth of insight that goes beyond a cursory analysis of just another position player.

Show us what the left guard does to prepare for a game. What does the right tackle think about when he scans a defense? Is an outside linebacker watching film? What does a team physician think when he sees an injury occur?

Let's take a pole, guys and dolls, Who do you suppose will be the last person standing here in WP, and will do a "Dandy Don Meredith" of Monday Night Football fame, as he, or she warbles "Turn off the Lights, the party's over, they say that all good things must end"...even here on what was once indubitably the smartest blog site the www has ever known?

I'm afraid, Dear hearts, Ye Olde Crayola is on the Alabaster...

Howie TBOQ

WHH
